quiz.title: Physics Grade 11: Electricity and Magnetism
quiz.subtitle: Unit 9, Quiz 3: Advanced Coulomb's Law Calculations
quiz.subject: Physics

questions.question: Two small spheres with identical charges q are suspended from a single point by strings of length L. At equilibrium, the strings make an angle θ with the vertical. Which expression represents the electrostatic force Fe between them?
questions.explanation: In equilibrium, the horizontal electrostatic force balances the horizontal component of tension (T sinθ), while the vertical component (T cosθ) balances gravity (mg). Dividing these gives Fe/mg = tanθ.

questions.question: A +4.0 μC charge is at (0, 3) and a +4.0 μC charge is at (0, -3). What is the net force on a -2.0 μC charge placed at (4, 0)? (All coordinates in meters).
options: 9.2 x 10^-3 N away from the origin
questions.explanation: Distance to each charge is 5m. F_individual = (9e9 * 4e-6 * 2e-6)/25 = 0.00288 N. Vertical components cancel. Net force = 2 * F * cosθ = 2 * 0.00288 * (4/5) = 0.0046 N.

questions.question: A +Q charge and a +9Q charge are separated by distance L. At what distance from +Q is the net electric force on a third charge zero?
questions.explanation: Setting forces equal: kQq/x² = k(9Q)q/(L-x)². Taking the root: 1/x = 3/(L-x) -> L-x = 3x -> x = L/4.

questions.question: Two charges q1 = +8μC and q2 = -2μC are 20 cm apart. Where can a third charge be placed so that it experiences no net force?
options: 20 cm to the right of q2 (outside the charges)
20 cm to the left of q1
40 cm to the right of q2
questions.explanation: For opposite charges, equilibrium is outside, near the smaller charge. sqrt(8)/(0.2+x) = sqrt(2)/x -> 2/(0.2+x) = 1/x -> 2x = 0.2 + x -> x = 0.2m.

questions.question: Three identical charges +q are placed at the corners of an equilateral triangle with side length a. What is the magnitude of the net force on any one of the charges?
questions.explanation: The force is the vector sum of two forces (F = kq²/a²) at a 60° angle. Using the law of cosines: F_net = sqrt(F² + F² + 2F² cos 60°) = sqrt(3)F.

questions.question: Two charges A and B are separated by a distance R. If the charge on A is doubled, the charge on B is doubled, and the distance is halved, the force becomes:
options: The same as the original force.

questions.question: An electron and a proton are separated by 0.53 x 10^-10 m. How does the electrostatic force Fe compare to the gravitational force Fg between them?
options: Fe is roughly 10^39 times stronger than Fg.
Fe is roughly equal to Fg.
Fg is stronger because it is always attractive.
questions.explanation: At the subatomic scale, the high value of k compared to G makes electrostatic forces vastly more powerful than gravity.

questions.question: Three charges are at corners of a square of side L. q1=+q is at (0,L), q2=-q is at (0,0), and q3=+q is at (L,0). What is the magnitude of the net force on q2?
questions.explanation: q2 experiences two attractive forces (magnitude F=kq²/L²) along the x and y axes. The resultant is sqrt(F² + F²) = sqrt(2)F.

questions.question: Two identical point charges are 3.0 cm apart and experience a repulsive force of 0.040 N. What is the magnitude of each charge?
Two charges +q and -q are placed at (-d, 0) and (d, 0). A third charge +Q is placed at the origin. The net force on +Q is:
questions.explanation: +Q is pushed right by the charge at -d and pulled right by the charge at +d. Total force = kqQ/d² + kqQ/d² = 2kqQ/d² to the right.
